question: Will Randy Fine win the special election for Florida's 6th Congressional District?
reasoning:
Based on the gathered information, here are the key points regarding Randy Fine's candidacy in the special election for Florida's 6th Congressional District:

1. **Endorsements and Political Support**: Randy Fine has received endorsements from prominent figures such as President-elect Donald Trump, House Speaker Mike Johnson, and Senator Rick Scott. These endorsements are likely to boost his appeal among conservative voters in the district.

2. **Political Experience**: Randy Fine is a state senator with four terms in the Florida House, indicating significant political experience compared to his opponents.

3. **District Demographics**: The 6th Congressional District is a solidly conservative region, with nearly 46% of the electorate registered as Republicans, compared to fewer than 27% registered as Democrats. This demographic advantage is likely to favor Fine.

4. **Primary Election Results**: Randy Fine won the Republican primary with more than 80% of the vote, demonstrating strong support within his party.

5. **Campaign Financing**: Fine has raised over $426,000 for his campaign, more than double what his Democratic opponent, Josh Weil, has raised. This financial advantage could enhance his campaign's outreach and effectiveness.

6. **Voter Turnout**: Voter turnout in the primary was low, with less than 10% of registered voters participating. This could favor candidates with strong party support, such as Fine, in the general election.

Considering these factors, Randy Fine appears to have a strong chance of winning the special election, given his endorsements, political experience, financial resources, and the conservative nature of the district.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.85

# Florida's 6th Congressional District special election, 2025

120th →←
|
|
|
|
|
|
| Other 2025-2026 election coverage |
|

A special election to fill the seat representing [Florida's 6th Congressional District](https://ballotpedia.org/Florida%27s_6th_Congressional_District) in the [U.S. House](https://ballotpedia.org/U.S._House) will be held in 2025. Primaries were scheduled for January 28, 2025. The general election will be held April 1, 2025. The filing deadline was December 7, 2024.

The special election will fill the vacancy left by [Michael Waltz](https://ballotpedia.org/Michael_Waltz) (R), who was selected by [Donald Trump](https://ballotpedia.org/Donald_Trump) (R) to serve as national security advisor in his second presidential term.[[1]](https://ballotpedia.org#cite_note-1)

As of March 24, 2025, three [special elections](https://ballotpedia.org/Special_elections_to_the_119th_United_States_Congress_(2025-2026)) have been called for the [119th Congress](https://ballotpedia.org/119th_United_States_Congress). From the [113th Congress](https://ballotpedia.org/113th_Congress) to the [118th Congress](https://ballotpedia.org/118th_Congress), 80 special elections were held. For more data on historical congressional special elections, [click here](https://ballotpedia.org/Special_elections_to_the_119th_United_States_Congress_(2025-2026)#Historical_election_data).

This page focuses on Florida's 6th Congressional District special election. For more in-depth information on the district's special primaries, see the following pages:

[Florida's 6th Congressional District special election, 2025 (January 28 Democratic primary)](https://ballotpedia.org/Florida%27s_6th_Congressional_District_special_election,_2025_(January_28_Democratic_primary))[Florida's 6th Congressional District special election, 2025 (January 28 Republican primary)](https://ballotpedia.org/Florida%27s_6th_Congressional_District_special_election,_2025_(January_28_Republican_primary))

Multiple Republicans and Democrats will be joined by more marginal candidates in the battle to replace former U.S. Rep. **Mike Waltz**, who is currently slated to be President-elect **Donald Trump’s **National Security Adviser.

The qualification deadline of noon Saturday has passed, and the field is finalized for the Special Election in East-Central Florida’s 6th Congressional District.

Of the nine candidates in the mix, three are Republicans, and one in particular has the most significant advantage in the Primary.

[ Aaron Baker](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88859) of Sorrento and

[of Brooksville will face off against state Sen.](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88820)

**Ehsan Joarder****Randy Fine**of Brevard County.

Fine, elected in November after serving four terms in the Florida House, has earned endorsements from President-elect **Donald Trump**, House Speaker **Mike Johnson**, Sen. **Rick Scott**, and the American Israeli Public Affairs Committee, among others.

He has the advantage against his two opponents, who are comparatively unknown and inexperienced politically.

Multiple Democratic candidates are also presenting themselves for voters.

Daytona Beach’s **Purvi Bangdiwala****, **Elkton’s [ George Selmont](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88846), and Orlando’s

[are all on the ballot.](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88857)

**Josh Weil**Selmont has run for Congress before.

In 2018, he lost to Rep. **John Rutherford** in Florida’s 4th Congressional District, getting 32% of the vote in a heavily Republican area that included much of Duval County and part of St. Johns.

Other candidates will advance automatically to the General Election ballot.

**Chuck Sheridan** of Merritt Island will be a write-in, while 2024 presidential candidate **Randall Terry** will run as a no-party candidate. **Andrew Parrott** will run under the Libertarian banner.

title: Trump-endorsed US House candidates sail to special election
author: Alex Pickett
url: https://www.courthousenews.com/trump-endorsed-us-house-candidates-sail-to-special-election/
hostname: courthousenews.com
description: Florida Chief Financial Officer Jimmy Patronis and state Senator Randy Fine vie against longshot Democratic candidates in April.
sitename: Courthousenews
date: 2025-03-22
---
(CN) — Florida voters narrowed down their choices for two new congressional representatives on Tuesday in the state’s special election primary, setting the stage for an April election that will likely add to Republicans’ slim majority in the U.S. House.

Florida Chief Financial Officer Jimmy Patronis won his primary in the state’s 1st Congressional District by 60% against nine other challengers for the seat formerly held by Matt Gaetz, who resigned in November after President Donald Trump nominated him for U.S. attorney general. Gaetz withdrew consideration for the nation’s top prosecutor amid [allegations](https://www.courthousenews.com/house-ethics-finds-substantial-evidence-gaetz-had-sex-with-minor-used-illicit-drugs/) of sexual misconduct and drug abuse.

Patronis, endorsed by Trump, will face Democrat Gay Valimont, a gun violence prevention activist, and Stephen Broden, a pastor from Texas with no party affiliation.

In the 6th Congressional District that includes rural parts of the Atlantic Coast, state Senator Randy Fine beat out two other Republicans for the seat formerly held by Mike Waltz, who Trump hired as his national security adviser. Waltz’s new position does not require confirmation by the U.S. Senate, and he resigned on Trump’s [Inauguration](https://www.courthousenews.com/bitter-cold-temps-create-inaugural-split-screen-with-trump-supporters-scattered-around-dc/) Day.

Fine, also endorsed by Trump, will face Josh Weil, a teacher, in April’s special election.

Both congressional districts are in solidly conservative regions that overwhelmingly voted for Gaetz, Waltz and Trump in November.

In the 1st Congressional District, Patronis took in more than $970,000 in contributions, according to federal campaign finance reports.

One of his rivals, former Escambia County Commissioner Gene Valentino, raised half that amount, focusing his campaign on economic development in the panhandle. Navy veteran Aaron Dimmock, recruited by former U.S. House Speaker Kevin McCarthy to run against Gaetz last year, also lagged behind Patronis in contributions.

Multiple Republicans and Democrats will be joined by more marginal candidates in the battle to replace former U.S. Rep. **Mike Waltz**, who is currently slated to be President-elect **Donald Trump’s **National Security Adviser.

The qualification deadline of noon Saturday has passed, and the field is finalized for the Special Election in East-Central Florida’s 6th Congressional District.

Of the nine candidates in the mix, three are Republicans, and one in particular has the most significant advantage in the Primary.

[ Aaron Baker](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88859) of Sorrento and

[of Brooksville will face off against state Sen.](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88820)

**Ehsan Joarder****Randy Fine**of Brevard County.

Fine, elected in November after serving four terms in the Florida House, has earned endorsements from President-elect **Donald Trump**, House Speaker **Mike Johnson**, Sen. **Rick Scott**, and the American Israeli Public Affairs Committee, among others.

He has the advantage against his two opponents, who are comparatively unknown and inexperienced politically.

Multiple Democratic candidates are also presenting themselves for voters.

Daytona Beach’s **Purvi Bangdiwala****, **Elkton’s [ George Selmont](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88846), and Orlando’s

[are all on the ballot.](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88857)

**Josh Weil**Selmont has run for Congress before.

In 2018, he lost to Rep. **John Rutherford** in Florida’s 4th Congressional District, getting 32% of the vote in a heavily Republican area that included much of Duval County and part of St. Johns.

Other candidates will advance automatically to the General Election ballot.

**Chuck Sheridan** of Merritt Island will be a write-in, while 2024 presidential candidate **Randall Terry** will run as a no-party candidate. **Andrew Parrott** will run under the Libertarian banner.

title: Trump-endorsed US House candidates sail to special election
author: Alex Pickett
url: https://www.courthousenews.com/trump-endorsed-us-house-candidates-sail-to-special-election/
hostname: courthousenews.com
description: Florida Chief Financial Officer Jimmy Patronis and state Senator Randy Fine vie against longshot Democratic candidates in April.
sitename: Courthousenews
date: 2025-03-22
---
(CN) — Florida voters narrowed down their choices for two new congressional representatives on Tuesday in the state’s special election primary, setting the stage for an April election that will likely add to Republicans’ slim majority in the U.S. House.

Florida Chief Financial Officer Jimmy Patronis won his primary in the state’s 1st Congressional District by 60% against nine other challengers for the seat formerly held by Matt Gaetz, who resigned in November after President Donald Trump nominated him for U.S. attorney general. Gaetz withdrew consideration for the nation’s top prosecutor amid [allegations](https://www.courthousenews.com/house-ethics-finds-substantial-evidence-gaetz-had-sex-with-minor-used-illicit-drugs/) of sexual misconduct and drug abuse.

Patronis, endorsed by Trump, will face Democrat Gay Valimont, a gun violence prevention activist, and Stephen Broden, a pastor from Texas with no party affiliation.

In the 6th Congressional District that includes rural parts of the Atlantic Coast, state Senator Randy Fine beat out two other Republicans for the seat formerly held by Mike Waltz, who Trump hired as his national security adviser. Waltz’s new position does not require confirmation by the U.S. Senate, and he resigned on Trump’s [Inauguration](https://www.courthousenews.com/bitter-cold-temps-create-inaugural-split-screen-with-trump-supporters-scattered-around-dc/) Day.

Fine, also endorsed by Trump, will face Josh Weil, a teacher, in April’s special election.

Both congressional districts are in solidly conservative regions that overwhelmingly voted for Gaetz, Waltz and Trump in November.

In the 1st Congressional District, Patronis took in more than $970,000 in contributions, according to federal campaign finance reports.

One of his rivals, former Escambia County Commissioner Gene Valentino, raised half that amount, focusing his campaign on economic development in the panhandle. Navy veteran Aaron Dimmock, recruited by former U.S. House Speaker Kevin McCarthy to run against Gaetz last year, also lagged behind Patronis in contributions.

Oth…

# Florida's 6th Congressional District special election, 2025

120th →←
|
|
|
|
|
|
| Other 2025-2026 election coverage |
|

A special election to fill the seat representing [Florida's 6th Congressional District](https://ballotpedia.org/Florida%27s_6th_Congressional_District) in the [U.S. House](https://ballotpedia.org/U.S._House) will be held in 2025. Primaries were scheduled for January 28, 2025. The general election will be held April 1, 2025. The filing deadline was December 7, 2024.

The special election will fill the vacancy left by [Michael Waltz](https://ballotpedia.org/Michael_Waltz) (R), who was selected by [Donald Trump](https://ballotpedia.org/Donald_Trump) (R) to serve as national security advisor in his second presidential term.[[1]](https://ballotpedia.org#cite_note-1)

As of March 24, 2025, three [special elections](https://ballotpedia.org/Special_elections_to_the_119th_United_States_Congress_(2025-2026)) have been called for the [119th Congress](https://ballotpedia.org/119th_United_States_Congress). From the [113th Congress](https://ballotpedia.org/113th_Congress) to the [118th Congress](https://ballotpedia.org/118th_Congress), 80 special elections were held. For more data on historical congressional special elections, [click here](https://ballotpedia.org/Special_elections_to_the_119th_United_States_Congress_(2025-2026)#Historical_election_data).

This page focuses on Florida's 6th Congressional District special election. For more in-depth information on the district's special primaries, see the following pages:

title: Nine candidates qualify for race to replace Mike Waltz in CD 6
author: A G Gancarski

description: A state senator, a former presidential candidate, and a previous candidate for Congress are in the mix.

date: 2024-12-07
categories: ['Headlines', 'Specials']

Multiple Republicans and Democrats will be joined by more marginal candidates in the battle to replace former U.S. Rep. **Mike Waltz**, who is currently slated to be President-elect **Donald Trump’s **National Security Adviser.

The qualification deadline of noon Saturday has passed, and the field is finalized for the Special Election in East-Central Florida’s 6th Congressional District.

Of the nine candidates in the mix, three are Republicans, and one in particular has the most significant advantage in the Primary.

[ Aaron Baker](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88859) of Sorrento and

[of Brooksville will face off against state Sen.](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88820)

**Ehsan Joarder****Randy Fine**of Brevard County.

Fine, elected in November after serving four terms in the Florida House, has earned endorsements from President-elect **Donald Trump**, House Speaker **Mike Johnson**, Sen. **Rick Scott**, and the American Israeli Public Affairs Committee, among others.

He has the advantage against his two opponents, who are comparatively unknown and inexperienced politically.

Multiple Democratic candidates are also presenting themselves for voters.

Daytona Beach’s **Purvi Bangdiwala****, **Elkton’s [ George Selmont](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88846), and Orlando’s

[are all on the ballot.](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/candidates/CanDetail.asp?account=88857)

**Josh Weil**Selmont has run for Congress before.

In 2018, he lost to Rep. **John Rutherford** in Florida’s 4th Congressional District, getting 32% of the vote in a heavily Republican area that included much of Duval County and part of St. Johns.

Other candidates will advance automatically to the General Election ballot.

**Chuck Sheridan** of Merritt Island will be a write-in, while 2024 presidential candidate **Randall Terry** will run as a no-party candidate. **Andrew Parrott** will run under the Libertarian banner.

{"url": "https://www.courthousenews.com/trump-endorsed-us-house-candidates-sail-to-special-election/", "snippet": "---
title: Trump-endorsed US House candidates sail to special election
author: Alex Pickett
url: https://www.courthousenews.com/trump-endorsed-us-house-candidates-sail-to-special-election/
hostname: courthousenews.com
description: Florida Chief Financial Officer Jimmy Patronis and state Senator Randy Fine vie against longshot Democratic candidates in April.
sitename: Courthousenews
date: 2025-03-22
---
(CN) — Florida voters narrowed down their choices for two new congressional representatives on Tuesday in the state’s special election primary, setting the stage for an April election that will likely add to Republicans’ slim majority in the U.S. House.

Florida Chief Financial Officer Jimmy Patronis won his primary in the state’s 1st Congressional District by 60% against nine other challengers for the seat formerly held by Matt Gaetz, who resigned in November after President Donald Trump nominated him for U.S. attorney general. Gaetz withdrew consideration for the nation’s top prosecutor amid [allegations](https://www.courthousenews.com/house-ethics-finds-substantial-evidence-gaetz-had-sex-with-minor-used-illicit-drugs/) of sexual misconduct and drug abuse.

Patronis, endorsed by Trump, will face Democrat Gay Valimont, a gun violence prevention activist, and Stephen Broden, a pastor from Texas with no party affiliation.

In the 6th Congressional District that includes rural parts of the Atlantic Coast, state Senator Randy Fine beat out two other Republicans for the seat formerly held by Mike Waltz, who Trump hired as his national security adviser. Waltz’s new position does not require confirmation by the U.S. Senate, and he resigned on Trump’s [Inauguration](https://www.courthousenews.com/bitter-cold-temps-create-inaugural-split-screen-with-trump-supporters-scattered-around-dc/) Day.

Fine, also endorsed by Trump, will face Josh Weil, a teacher, in April’s special election.

Both congressional districts are in solidly conservative regions that overwhelmingly voted for Gaetz, Waltz and Trump in November.

In the 1st Congressional District, Patronis took in more than $970,000 in contributions, according to federal campaign finance reports.

One of his rivals, former Escambia County Commissioner Gene Valentino, raised half that amount, focusing his campaign on economic development in the panhandle. Navy veteran Aaron Dimmock, recruited by former U.S. House Speaker Kevin McCarthy to run against Gaetz last year, also lagged behind Patronis in contributions.

Based on the gathered information, here are the key points regarding Randy Fine's candidacy in the special election for Florida's 6th Congressional District:

1. **Endorsements and Political Support**: Randy Fine has received endorsements from prominent figures such as President-elect Donald Trump, House Speaker Mike Johnson, and Senator Rick Scott. These endorsements are likely to boost his appeal among conservative voters in the district.

2. **Political Experience**: Randy Fine is a state senator with four terms in the Florida House, indicating significant political experience compared to his opponents.

3. **District Demographics**: The 6th Congressional District is a solidly conservative region, with nearly 46% of the electorate registered as Republicans, compared to fewer than 27% registered as Democrats. This demographic advantage is likely to favor Fine.

4. **Primary Election Results**: Randy Fine won the Republican primary with more than 80% of the vote, demonstrating strong support within his party.

5. **Campaign Financing**: Fine has raised over $426,000 for his campaign, more than double what his Democratic opponent, Josh Weil, has raised. This financial advantage could enhance his campaign's outreach and effectiveness.

6. **Voter Turnout**: Voter turnout in the primary was low, with less than 10% of registered voters participating. This could favor candidates with strong party support, such as Fine, in the general election.

Considering these factors, Randy Fine appears to have a strong chance of winning the special election, given his endorsements, political experience, financial resources, and the conservative nature of the district.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.85
